update.description:
First part of schematic view (without icons)

* added `qgv` library (LGPL) located at `gazebo/gui/model/qgv` to help draw graphs in Qt.

* added optional dependency on libgraphviz-dev for doing graph layouts

To open the schematic view:

1. Go in model editor

1. From the menubar: Window -> Schematic View
update.title: Add schematic view to model editor

content.raw:
I've been trying to reproduce it but can't seem to get this assert. I also ran tests 100 times to make sure it's not a race condition. At this point, I am inclined to leave it like this and ticket an issue for it in case it happens again.

If anyone know how to stop asserts from upstream library from crashing gazebo, we could do probably add that in.
content.html:
I've been trying to reproduce it but can't seem to get this assert. I also ran tests 100 times to make sure it's not a race condition. At this point, I am inclined to leave it like this and ticket an issue for it in case it happens again.

If anyone know how to stop asserts from upstream library from crashing gazebo, we could do probably add that in.

I got a weird crash which I'm not able to reproduce. It happened when I deleted a link:

~~~
newtrap: Trapezoid-table overflow 441
gzclient: trapezoid.c:88: newtrap: Assertion `0' failed.

It seems to be a graphviz problem, the assert is [here](http://fossies.org/dox/graphviz-2.38.0/trapezoid_8c_source.html)

content.raw:
I did some style changes on 254ec62. I also added some lines to the test and did a possible fix for the centring issue.

I was trying to add a test to remove a node which has edges and then check that the edges were removed as well, but trying to do that causes a crash (comment out lines [74 and 75](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/254ec6272f12767245d9a6e933b5e341178f2133#Lgazebo/gui/model/SchematicViewWidget_TEST.ccT74)). As far as I could tell, it was a problem with QGV, so I guess as long as we make sure never to call that function on nodes with edges we should be fine, as I believe you're currently doing.
content.html:
I did some style changes on 254ec62. I also added some lines to the test and did a possible fix for the centring issue.

I was trying to add a test to remove a node which has edges and then check that the edges were removed as well, but trying to do that causes a crash (comment out lines 74 and 75). As far as I could tell, it was a problem with QGV, so I guess as long as we make sure never to call that function on nodes with edges we should be fine, as I believe you're currently doing.

pullrequest.title: Add schematic view to model editor

content.raw:
1 & 2. It looks much better now centralized. Just a little detail though, if you open a complex model like the PR2 and then delete most of the links, the schematic view seems to maintain its scrollable size with a lot of empty space on the right and bottom and all the remaining links on the top-left. Also, the size seems to be remembered if you leave the editor and enter again with a completely new model.

4- Way to reproduce: I created many joints between two links (6 or 7), then deleted one of the links - the link box disappears but the joint lines remain.
content.html:
1 & 2. It looks much better now centralized. Just a little detail though, if you open a complex model like the PR2 and then delete most of the links, the schematic view seems to maintain its scrollable size with a lot of empty space on the right and bottom and all the remaining links on the top-left. Also, the size seems to be remembered if you leave the editor and enter again with a completely new model.

4- Way to reproduce: I created many joints between two links (6 or 7), then deleted one of the links - the link box disappears but the joint lines remain.

content.raw:
I would put your modifications in the section 2 of [the license](https://www.gnu.org/licenses/lgpl.html) so yes, Ian either you license your code (only speaking about modifications to the qgv) as LGPL or as a GPL.

There is no problem about linking any kind of software against LGPL libraries, in our case using LGPL from Apache license. Even if we do [static linking](http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#LGPLStaticVsDynamic), we are providing the source code of the library.
content.html:
I would put your modifications in the section 2 of the license so yes, Ian either you license your code (only speaking about modifications to the qgv) as LGPL or as a GPL.

There is no problem about linking any kind of software against LGPL libraries, in our case using LGPL from Apache license. Even if we do static linking, we are providing the source code of the library.

pull_request.title: Add schematic view to model editor

pullrequest.title: Add schematic view to model editor

content.raw:
Awesome, the schematic view really helps understand how things are connected in the model!

Some usability comments with various degrees of importance:

1. The boxes don't start in the center of the view, and the model seems to be built from the center to the right, leaving the whole left area always empty.

1. The scrollable area is too large for models with few links/joints and too small for complex models. It would be nice to:

    * Remove scroll bars when all items fit the screen
    * Allow scroll bar to go all the way to the right-most box at any zoom level. Right now if you load the PR2 for example, the links on the far right are only visible when zoomed out.

1.  Is there a way to bring up the inspector from the schematic view right now, or is that coming later?

1. Some arrows remain after the joints have been deleted.

1. Long link names don't fit the box

1. When you select a link, the color changes and a bounding box appears, clicking outside changes the color, but the box only disappears when moving the view.
content.html:
Awesome, the schematic view really helps understand how things are connected in the model!

Some usability comments with various degrees of importance:

  1. The boxes don't start in the center of the view, and the model seems to be built from the center to the right, leaving the whole left area always empty.

  2. The scrollable area is too large for models with few links/joints and too small for complex models. It would be nice to:

    • Remove scroll bars when all items fit the screen
    • Allow scroll bar to go all the way to the right-most box at any zoom level. Right now if you load the PR2 for example, the links on the far right are only visible when zoomed out.

  3. Is there a way to bring up the inspector from the schematic view right now, or is that coming later?

  4. Some arrows remain after the joints have been deleted.

  5. Long link names don't fit the box

  6. When you select a link, the color changes and a bounding box appears, clicking outside changes the color, but the box only disappears when moving the view.

content.raw:
It looks like the qgv code was modified in the following commits:

* b9f3f3eb7377
* 571b2a37e9c3
* 71de2c83f555
* 555afe925206
* 8d6c640458e7
* 1a87370aaaad
* 63dd2ae14321
* 23260c2a1db2

I'd be more comfortable if we reverted the code to the original form.  We can disable the code check script and use an extra header file with pragmas to disable warnings. Were there any other changes you had to make?
content.html:
It looks like the qgv code was modified in the following commits:

  • b9f3f3eb7377
  • 571b2a37e9c3
  • 71de2c83f555
  • 555afe925206
  • 8d6c640458e7
  • 1a87370aaaad
  • 63dd2ae14321
  • 23260c2a1db2

I'd be more comfortable if we reverted the code to the original form. We can disable the code check script and use an extra header file with pragmas to disable warnings. Were there any other changes you had to make?

content.raw: From a licensing point of view, we have a copy of the `qgv` source code, and we are compiling it into a dynamic library. So as long as we don't modify it, I think that's ok. I think @\_jrivero_ may need to check this with regard to debian requirements for license notices.
content.html: From a licensing point of view, we have a copy of the qgv source code, and we are compiling it into a dynamic library. So as long as we don't modify it, I think that's ok. I think @_jrivero_ may need to check this with regard to debian requirements for license notices.
